heading: Title
text: Revolutionizing Asymmetric Synthesis: The Emergence of Next-Gen Chiral Phase-Transfer Catalysts.

heading: Abstract
text: Phase-transfer catalysis is a highly useful method for organic synthesis, and asymmetric phase-transfer catalysis using chiral catalysts has become a popular area of research over the past three decades. While effective chiral catalysts have already been developed and utilized for practical asymmetric transformations, there is still a need for further design and development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts in organic chemistry. This review highlights recent examples of newly designed effective chiral phase-transfer catalysts, demonstrating the continued interest and importance of this research area.

heading: Introduction
text: Phase-transfer catalysis is a highly versatile method for organic synthesis that is widely used in both industry and academia. It offers several advantages, including simple experimental operations, mild reaction conditions, inexpensive and environmentally friendly reagents and solvents, and the ability to conduct large-scale preparations in process chemistry. Over the past three decades, asymmetric phase-transfer catalysis has become a topic of great scientific interest, with notable achievements in various bond formation reactions under mild phase-transfer-catalyzed conditions. The use of structurally well-defined chiral, non-racemic catalysts has been particularly successful, with cinchona alkaloid-derived tetraalkylammonium salts and binaphthyl-modified tetraalkylammonium salts being some of the most reliable and widely applicable chiral phase-transfer catalysts. Other effective chiral phase-transfer catalysts include TADDOL-derived and/or multicyclic onium salts and crown ethers. Anion phase-transfer catalysis with chiral phosphoric acid catalysts is a new concept in phase-transfer catalysis. Overall, the development of bifunctional catalysts and new catalyst designs has expanded the possibilities of phase-transfer catalysis for organic synthesis.

heading: Review
text: The use of chiral phase-transfer catalysts in organic chemistry has proven to be efficient and practical in achieving asymmetric transformations. The exchange of lipophilic, bulky chiral phosphate anions with anions associated with selectfluor has been successful in bringing the reagent into solution and mediating asymmetric fluorinations. Chiral carboxylic acid has also been effective as an anionic phase-transfer catalyst. While these catalysts have been useful, there is still a need for further design and development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts. Recent examples of newly designed effective chiral phase-transfer catalysts have emerged in the last few years. The high utility and practicability of phase-transfer-catalyzed reactions make the development of new catalysts an attractive research subject in organic chemistry. Representative chiral phase-transfer catalysts are shown in Figure 1.

heading: Amino Acid-Derived Catalysts
text: The new chiral 1,2,3-triazolium catalysts designed by Ooi and co-workers have shown promising results in asymmetric phase-transfer reactions. The catalysts were easily prepared from α-amino acids and were found to be essential in achieving highly enantioselective reactions. The double hydrogen-bonding by the triazolium C(5)-H proton and the amide N-H proton of the catalyst to anion was found to be crucial in achieving good enantioselectivity. Further fine-tuning of the catalyst improved the enantioselectivity, and the highly selective reaction was achieved by the use of optimized catalyst 22b. The new chiral 1,2,3-triazolium catalysts could also be applied to other asymmetric phase-transfer reactions.

heading: Highly Enantioselective Reactions Catalyzed By Chiral 2-Oxopyrimidinium Salt Catalysts In Phase-Transfer Chemistry
text: The use of specific catalysts has been successful in achieving highly enantioselective reactions in various chemical transformations. For example, catalysts 22c and 22d were able to produce products 27 and 28 with good enantioselectivity in the Mannich reaction of cyanosulfones. Catalyst 22 was also effective in constructing contiguous all-carbon quaternary stereocenters in the ring-opening reaction of racemic 2,2-disubstituted aziridine and 3-substituted oxindole. Catalyst 22f was used in the phase-transfer cyanation of alkylideneindolenine to obtain product 32. The development of catalyst 33 by Hii and co-workers has also shown promise in achieving highly enantioselective reactions, such as the conjugate addition of glycine derivative 34 with methyl vinyl ketone to obtain α-amino acid derivative 35. The success of these reactions highlights the importance of fine-tuning catalysts for efficient asymmetric transformations.

heading: Scheme 3 Chiral 2-Oxopyrimidinium Salt Catalyst.
text: The use of chiral bifunctional catalysts in phase-transfer reactions has shown promising results in achieving high enantioselectivity. Catalysts such as tetraalkylammonium bromide 36a and quaternary ammonium salt 36c have been developed and tested in reactions such as the addition of thiophenol to imine precursor 37 and the alkylation of azlactone 40a, respectively. These reactions have resulted in the production of products 38 and 41a with good enantioselectivity. The use of chiral bifunctional catalysts, therefore, presents a potential solution for achieving high enantioselectivity in phase-transfer reactions.

heading: Scheme 4
text: Chiral bifunctional tetraalkylammonium salts with thiourea or urea moieties have been developed by Zhao and co-workers. They also created bifunctional quaternary phosphonium salts, including chiral quaternary phosphonium bromide 42a with an amide moiety that efficiently promotes asymmetric conjugate addition of 3-phenyloxindole 24b under phase-transfer conditions. The related catalyst 42b can be used for asymmetric desymmetrization of meso-aziridine 44 with thiophenol, and product 45 is obtained with moderate enantioselectivity. Bifunctional phosphonium bromide catalyst 42c with a thiourea moiety is used for asymmetric aza-Henry reaction of imine precursor 37 with nitromethane to give product 39 with high enantioselectivity. Dipeptide-derived multifunctional phosphonium bromide 42d is an effective catalyst for asymmetric cyclization via tandem Michael addition/intramolecular S N 2 reaction with substrate 46 and malonate, resulting in cyclopentane derivative 47 with high enantioselectivity. The bifunctional design of the catalysts is essential for achieving highly enantioselective reactions.

heading: Chiral Diamine-Derived Catalysts
text: The article discusses the development of various chiral catalysts for use in asymmetric phase-transfer reactions. Ooi and co-workers developed a P-spiro chiral tetraaminophosphonium salt catalyst, which was effective in the enantioselective alkylation of azlactone. Tan and co-workers developed chiral pentanidium salt catalysts, which were effective in various reactions including conjugate addition and asymmetric oxidation. Waser and Massa et al. developed chiral bifunctional tetraalkylammonium salt catalysts, which were effective in asymmetric fluorination and aldol-initiated cascade reactions. These catalysts were designed using various chiral diamine-derived bifunctional quaternary ammonium salts and were fine-tuned to achieve highly enantioselective phase-transfer reactions. Overall, the development of these chiral catalysts provides a novel and efficient method for the synthesis of various chiral compounds, including peptides and α-amino acids.

heading: Chiral Phosphine-Derived Catalysts
text: Our research focused on developing effective chiral quaternary phosphonium bromides as phase-transfer catalysts. While chiral phosphine compounds have been extensively studied as ligands for metal catalysts, we aimed to construct a catalyst library of chiral quaternary phosphonium salts using commercially available chiral phosphine compounds as catalyst precursors. By benzylation of corresponding commercially available phosphines, we were able to construct a library of chiral quaternary phosphonium salt catalysts with various structures. After careful optimization, we found that the bifunctional catalyst of type 68 was effective for asymmetric conjugate addition and sulfenylation reactions. The reactions were efficiently promoted by phosphonium bromide 68a with low catalyst loading under base-free neutral phase-transfer conditions, resulting in high yield and enantioselectivity. Our approach allows for the facile construction of a catalyst library of chiral quaternary phosphonium salts, providing a promising avenue for the development of practical asymmetric reactions.

heading: Scheme 12
text: The article discusses the use of chiral bifunctional phosphonium salts as catalysts for various asymmetric reactions. The authors prepared new bifunctional phosphonium salts with amide or urea moieties and tested their ability to catalyze reactions such as sulfenylation and chlorination of β-keto esters, as well as asymmetric nucleophilic aromatic substitution reactions. The results showed that the tunable acidity of the amide moiety of the catalysts could lead to further possibilities for asymmetric transformations. The authors also found that the newly-designed chiral bifunctional quaternary phosphonium bromide with a urea moiety gave high yields and enantioselectivities in the asymmetric nucleophilic aromatic substitution reaction. Overall, the use of chiral bifunctional phosphonium salts as catalysts provides a promising approach for the synthesis of biologically interesting compounds with high stereocontrol.

heading: Conclusions
text: This review highlights the recent development of new chiral phase-transfer catalysts for asymmetric reactions. The design of these catalysts required careful optimization to achieve highly enantioselective reactions. Bifunctional design of catalysts with an amide or urea moiety also proved effective. However, the current problem with the development of asymmetric phase-transfer reactions is the need for troublesome catalyst screening for each reaction to achieve high enantioselectivity. Computational studies may aid in understanding catalyst-substrate interactions and aid in the selection and design of appropriate chiral phase-transfer catalysts. The design of these new catalysts may inspire new ideas for the development of effective chiral catalysts in the future.

heading: References
